title: Martha Hatfield
text:
Martha Hatfield (or "Hatfeild") (also known as The Wise Virgin) (born 27 September 1640) was an English <a href="Puritan">Puritan</a> <a href="prophet">prophet</a>.
Hatfield was born in <a href="Leighton%2C%20North%20Yorkshire">Leighton, North Yorkshire</a>, England in the 17th century, daughter of Anthony Hatfield (1598-1655/6; the family name is more commonly encountered as "Hatfeild"), of <a href="Laughton-en-le-Morthen">Laughton-en-le-Morthen</a>, near <a href="Rotherham">Rotherham</a>, and Faith (d. 1659), daughter of George Westby, of Gilthwaite, Rotherham. The Hatfield family were Yorkshire gentry, originally of <a href="Ecclesfield">Ecclesfield</a>, coming to own the manor of <a href="Thorp%20Arch">Thorp Arch</a> in the eighteenth century through marriage with the Gossip family of that place.
In April 1652, Hatfield became ill with a type of <a href="catalepsy">catalepsy</a>. She became <a href="paralyzed">paralyzed</a>, <a href="blindness">blind</a>, <a href="deaf">deaf</a> and <a href="muteness">mute</a>. This lasted for seventeen days. When she recovered she began "rambling" about religious subjects and started quoting <a href="scriptures">scriptures</a>. What she said was documented by John and Peter, the songs of <a href="Edward%20Rodes">Edward Rodes</a>, and another man named John Cromwell. On 8 September 1652 she became mute again. She remained mute until 7 December 1652. However, her second recovery did not have any prophetic moments.
In 1653, her uncle, James Fisher, who founded the first <a href="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a> church in <a href="Sheffield%2C%20England">Sheffield, England</a>, wrote a book about Hatfield and her prophetic dialogue called "The Wise Virgin". The book was a best seller and was reprinted multiple times.
